list.title: Question 4
list.content:
The coefficient of the variable $x5$ in the expansion of $(x+2a)8$, where $a∈R$, is $56$.
Find the value of $a$.
list.markScheme:
Using the binomial theorem, we have
$$$(x+2a)8​=x8+(18​)(x)7(2a)1+...+(r8​)(x)(8−r)(2a)r+...+(2a)8​(M1)​$$$
We need to identify the $rth$ term which includes $x5$, hence, $r=8−5=3$,
$$$(A1)$$$
Therefore
$$$(38​)(x5)(2a)3​=56x5​A1​$$$
Using the formula we can evaluate the binomial coefficient
$$$(38​)​=3!5!8!​=56​A1​$$$
$$$(56)(x5)(8a3)8a3a3​=56x5=1=81​a=21​​​A1A1​$$$

list.title: Question 6
list.content:
Show that $(2n−1)3+(2n+1)3=16n3+12n$ for $n∈Z$.
[3]



Hence, or otherwise, prove that the sum of the cubes of any two
consecutive odd integers is divisible by four. [3]
list.markScheme:
We have
$$$(2n−1)3​=(2n)3−3(2n)2+3(2n)−1=8n3−12n2+6n−1​$$$
and
$$$(2n+1)3​=(2n)3+3(2n)2+3(2n)+1=8n3+12n2+6n+1​$$$
Summing our expressions for $(2n−1)3$ and $(2n+1)3$, we get
$$$(2n−1)3+(2n+1)3​=8n3−12n2+6n−1​+8n3+12n2+6n+1​​$$$
Hence we get
$$$(2n−1)3+(2n+1)3=16n3+12n​​$$$


Let $2n−1$ and $2n+1$ be two consecutive odd integers for some
$n∈Z$.
The sum of the cubes of $2n−1$ and $2n+1$ is
$$$(2n−1)3+(2n+1)3​=16n3+12n[by part (a)]=4n(4n2+3)[multiple of 4]​$$$
Hence the sum of the cubes of any two consecutive odd integers is
divisible by four.

list.title: Question 7
list.content:
The third term, in descending powers of $x$, in the expansion of $(x+p)8$ is $252x6$. Find the
possible values of $p$.
list.markScheme:
Using the binomial theorem, we have
$$$252x6​=(28​)(x8−2)(p2)(1)​$$$
Hence, solving the equation $(1)$ for $p$, we get
$$$252x6252​=28(x6)(p2)=28p2​$$$
$$$p=±3​[by using G.D.C.]$$$

list.title: Question 9
list.content:
In the expansion of $(a+bx)6$, the coefficient of the $x3$ term is $−2$ times the coefficient of the $x4$ term.
Determine the value of $ba​$.
list.markScheme:
From the formula booklet we can find the formula for a general term of the expansion
$$$(a+b)n​=...+(rn​)an−rbr+...​$$$
Using the general term above, we can write an expression for the $x3$ term and the $x4$ term.
$$$​(36​)(a)3(bx)3​(46​)(a)2(bx)4​A1A1​$$$
We can now use the information given to write an equation linking the coefficients of the two expressions above.
$$$​(36​)a3b3=−2×(46​)a2b4​M1​$$$
Using the formula we can evaluate the binomial coefficients and simplify
$$$hack​M1​$$$
$$$3!3!6!​a3b33!×3×2×16×5×4×3!​a3b320a3b3​=−2×4!2!6!​a2b4=−2×4!×2×16×5×4!​a2b4=−30a2b4​A1​$$$
We need to find the value of $ba​$ therefore we can rearrange the expression above
$$$a2b4a3b3​ba​​=20−30​=2−3​​=−1.5​A1​$$$

list.title: Question 11
list.content:
Let $f(x)=(x2+a)5$.
In the expansion of the derivative, $f′(x)$, the coefficient of the term
in $x5$ is $960$. Find the possible values of $a$.
list.markScheme:
Using the chain rule, we have
$$$f′(x)​=5(x2+a)4(2x)=10x(x2+a)4​$$$
Hence, using the binomial theorem, we
have
$$$960x5​=10x(24​)[(x2)4−2][a2](1)​$$$
Hence, if we solve the equation $(1)$ for $a$, we get
$$$960x5960​=10x[6][x4][a2]=60a2​$$$
$$$a=±4​[by using G.D.C.]$$$

Hence we get
$$$[coefficient of the term in x4](28​)[38−2p2]28[36p2]20412p2−17496p​=[coefficient of the term in x6]=(18​)[38−1p]=8[37p]=0​$$$
$$$p=76​​≈0.857...[by using G.D.C.]$$$

list.title: Question 14
list.content:
Consider the expansion of $bx(x+a)7​$, where $a>0$. The coefficient of the term in $x5$ is $2$, and the coefficient of the term in $x3$ is $1690$.
Find the value of $a$ and the value of $b$.
list.markScheme:
Because each term in the expansion of $(x+a)7$ will be divided by $bx$, we require the terms in $x6$ and $x4$. Using the Binomial Theorem, we have
$$$Term in x6Term in x4​=(17​)x6a=7x6a=(37​)x4a3=35x4a3​$$$
Dividing both these terms by $bx$ we get
$$$bx7x6a​bx35x4a3​​=b7x5a​=b35x3a3​​$$$
Given that the coefficient of $x5$ is $2$, and the coefficient of $x3$ is $1690$, we have
$$$b7a​b35a3​​=2=1690​$$$
And therefore
$$$7a35a3​=2b=1690b​[1][2]​$$$
Dividing equation [2] by equation [1] we have
$$$7a35a3​5a2a2a​=2b1690b​=845=169=±13​$$$
Given that $a>0$, $a=13​$. Substituting into equation [1],
$$$7a7(13)​=2b=2bb=45.5​​$$$

list.title: Question 15
list.content:
Write $3x2+x−23x−7​$ in form $x+1A​+3x−2B​$, where $x=−1,32​.$[2]



Hence determine the first three terms of the binomial expansion of $3x2+x−23x−7​$.[5]
list.markScheme:
The process of rewriting a single fraction as two (or more!) fractions is known as partial fractions.
Let's setup an identity using the information given, this means the identity is true for all valid values of $x$.
$$$3x2+x−23x−7​​≡x+1A​+3x−2B​​$$$
We can then multiply throughout by $3x2+x−2$ to get
$$$3x−7​=(3x−2)A+(x+1)B​(M1)​$$$
Next expand the R.H.S. and then collect together the coefficients of $x$ and the constant
$$$3x−73x−7​=3Ax−2A+Bx+B=(3A+B)x−2A+B​$$$
We can now equate the coefficients of $x$ and the constant term, to form two equations
$$$3A+B−2A+B​=3=−7​$$$
Subtracting the two equations gives
$$$5AA​=10=2​$$$
And
$$$3(2)+BB​=3=−3​$$$
Hence we have
$$$3x2+x−23x−7​​=x+12​−3x−23​=x+12​+(−3x−23​)​[In the form required]​A1​$$$


First we can rewrite both quotients in index form
$$$2(x+1)−1−3(3x−2)−1​$$$
Next consider the given formula for the extension of the binomial theorem
$$$(a+b)n​=an(1+n(ab​)+2!n(n−1)​(ab​)2+...)​$$$
Let's begin with the first quotient
$$$2(x+1)−1​$$$
We can see that $a=1$, $b=x$ and $n=−1$, hence the first three terms are
$$$2(x+1)−1​=2×1−1(1+(−1)(1x​)+2!−1((−1)−1)​(1x​)2)=2−2x+2x2​(A1)​$$$
Now lets consider the other quotient
$$$−3(3x−2)−1​$$$
This one is not as straight forward.
In order to use the formula effectively it is best to try and rewrite the quotient by factorising out the $an$ term, this is the constant term inside the bracket
$$$−3(3x−2)−1​=−3(−2(−23​x+1))−1=−3×(−2)−1(1−23​x)−1=23​(1−23​x)−1​$$$
In this form we can now see that $a=1$, $b=−23​x$ and $n=−1$, hence we get
$$$23​(1−23​x)−1​=23​(1+(−1)(−23​x)+2!−1((−1)−1)​(−23​x)2)=23​(1+23​x+49​x2)=23​+49​x+827​x2​(M1)(A1)​$$$
Hence we need to sum the two results which gives
$$$2(x+1)−1−3(3x−2)−1​=2−2x+2x2+23​+49​x+827​x2=27​+41​x+843​x2​​M1A1​$$$

list.title: Question 16

list.markScheme:

$$$(2x6+qx2​)10​=k=0∑10​(k10​)[2x6]10−k[qx2​]k=k=0∑10​(k10​)[210−kq−k][x60−4k]​$$$
Hence we get
$$$[coefficient of the term in x40](510​)[210−5q−5]252[25q−5]​=12[coefficient of the term in x36]=12(610​)[210−6q−6]=12(210)[24q−6]​$$$
$$$q=5​[by using G.D.C.]$$$

list.title: Question 18
list.content:
In the expansion of $x(2x+1)n$, the coefficient of the term in $x3$
is $20n$, where $n∈Z+$. Find $n$.
list.markScheme:
Using the binomial theorem, we have
$$$20nx3​=x(2n​)[1n−2][(2x)2](1)​$$$
Hence, solving the equation $(1)$ for $n$, we get
$$$20nx320nx310n0​=x[2!(n−2)!n!​][4x2]=[2n(n−1)​][4x3]=n(n−1)=n(n−11)​$$$
$$$n=11​$$$

list.markScheme:

$$$40nx2​=(2n​)[1n−2][(2x)2](1)​$$$
Hence, solving the equation $(1)$ for $n$, we get
$$$40nx240n20n0​=[2!(n−2)!n!​][4x2]=[2n(n−1)​][4]=n(n−1)=n(n−21)​$$$
$$$n=21​$$$

list.title: Question 20
list.content:
Consider the following equation $2(rn​)=(r+1n​)$.
Show that it can be written as $3r+2=n$.


Now consider the following equation $7(r−1n​)=2(rn​)$.
Show that it can be written as $9r−2=2n$.  [4]





Consider the expansion
$$$(1+x)n=1+a1​x+...+ak−1​xk−1+ak​xk+ak+1​xk+1+...+xn​$$$
Where $ai​∈Q$ and $k∈Z$.
The coefficients of three consecutive terms of the expansion are such that
$$$7×ak−1​​=2×ak​ and 14×ak​=7×ak+1​​$$$

Find $n$. [3]
list.markScheme:
Using the combinations formula $(rn​)=r!(n−r)!n!​$ we can rewrite both the LHS and the RHS of the equation
$$$2(r!(n−r)!n!​)​=(r+1)!(n−(r+1))!n!​​$$$
Now we can simplify and rearrange the equation
$$$r!2(r+1)!​​=(n−r−1)!(n−r)!​​$$$
Rewrite the numerators using the concept $n!=n(n−1)!$
$$$r!2(r+1)r!​​=(n−r−1)!(n−r)(n−r−1)!​​M1​$$$
We can cancel out the factorial terms
$$$r!2(r+1)r!​2(r+1)​=(n−r−1)!​(n−r)(n−r−1)!​​=n−r3r+2=n​​A1​$$$
As required.


Rewrite the equation using the combinations formula and simplify in a similar way to part (a)
$$$7((r−1)!(n−(r−1))!n!​)(r−1)!(n−r+1)!7​(r−1)!7r!​(r−1)!​7r(r−1)!​​7r​=2(r!(n−r)!n!​)=r!(n−r)!2​=(n−r)!2(n−r+1)!​=(n−r)!​2(n−r+1)(n−r)!​​=2n−2r+29r−2=2n​​M1A1​$$$
As required.




We can begin by expanding $(1+x)n$, using the binomial theorem, in terms of $n$ and $r$.
$$$(1+x)n​=1+(1n​)x+(2n​)x2+...+(r−1n​)xr−1+(rn​)xr+(r+1n​)xr+1+...+xn​(M1)​$$$
The terms in red represent any three consecutive terms in the expansion.
We are told in the question the way in which the coefficients of three consecutive terms are related.
$$$(1+x)n=1+a1​x+...+ak−1​xk−1+ak​xk+ak+1​xk+1+...+xn​$$$
Hence we can use the information given to write the following two equations in terms of binomial coefficients
$$$​​7×ak−1​7(r−1n​)​=2×ak​=2(rn​)​​​14×ak​14(rn​)2(rn​)​=7×ak+1​=7(r+1n​)=(r+1n​)​​$$$
In part (a) we already rewrote these equations without the combination notation, lets call them $[1]$ and $[2]$.
We can now solve them simultaneously and find $n$ and $r$.
$$$3r+29r−2​=n[1]=2n[2]​M1​$$$
Multiply $[1]$ by $3$ and subtract equation $[2]$ from this $result$
$$$9r−9r+6−(−2)​=3n−2nn=8​​A1​$$$

list.title: Question 21
list.content:
Use the extension of the binomial theorem for $n∈Q$ to show that
$(1+x)2x​≈x−2x2+3x3$,
$∣x∣<1$.
list.markScheme:
We have
$$$(1+x)2x​​=x(1+x)−2​$$$
Using
the fractional binomial theorem, we have
$$$(1+x)−2​=k=0∑∞​(k−2​)xk[∣x∣<1]=1+(−2)x+2!(−2)(−3)​x2+3!(−2)(−3)(−4)​x3+⋯=1−2x+3x2−4x3+⋯​$$$
Hence we get
$$$x(1+x)−2​=x(1−2x+3x2−4x3+⋯)=x−2x2+3x3−4x4+⋯​$$$
For $∣x∣<1$, the
term in $xk$ is small for $k≥4$.
Hence we deduce
$$$(1+x)2x​≈x−2x2+3x3​[∣x∣<1]​$$$

list.title: Question 22
list.content:
Given that
$(5+nx)2(1+53​x)n=25+100x+⋯$,
find the value of $n$.
list.markScheme:
Using the binomial theorem, we have
$$$(5+nx)2(1+53​x)n​=[25+10nx+n2x2][k=0∑n​(kn​)[53x​]k](1)​$$$
The term in $x$ in the expansion of the product $(1)$ is
$$$25(1n​)[53x​]1+10nx(0n​)[53x​]0​=15nx+10nx=25nx​$$$
Hence we get
$$$25n​=100​$$$
$$$n=4​$$$

list.title: Question 24
list.content:
Given that $(1+x)3(1+px)4=1+qx+93x2+⋯+p4x7$, find
the possible values of $p$ and $q$.
list.markScheme:
Using Pascal triangle


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5ede89c3-3d7f-44a4-9286-c2554a148745/images/aebac82f-9280-4cf9-ad52-e4db6b3a6da0/d6143401ad9783a3554c63b7ab804d89d1d7b5f1.svg)


we have
$$$1+qx+93x2+⋯+p4x7​=(1+x)3(1+px)4=(1+3x+3x2+x3)(1+4px+6p2x2+4p3x3+p4x4)​$$$
Hence we get
$$$qxq​=4px+3x=4p+3(1)​$$$
and
$$$93x293​=6p2x2+12px2+3x2=6p2+12p+3(2)​$$$
Hence, solving the equation $(2)$ for $p$, we find
$$$6p2+12p+36p2+12p−90p2+2p−15(p+5)(p−3)p​=93=0=0=0=−5,3​$$$
Hence, substituting $p=−5,3$ in the
equation $(1)$, we obtain
$$$q​=4(−5)+3=−17​$$$
and
$$$q​=4(3)+3=15​$$$
Therefore
$p=−5,q=−17​$
and  $p=3,q=15​$

list.title: Question 26
list.content:
This question will investigate power series, as an extension to the
Binomial Theorem for negative and fractional indices.
A power series in $x$ is defined as a function of the form
$$$f(x)=a0​+a1​x+a2​x2+a3​x3+…$$$
where the
$ai​∈R$.

Expand $(1−x)5$ using the Binomial Theorem.[3]


Consider the geometric series
$$$S=1−x+x2−x3+x4−x5+⋯$$$




State for which values the geometric series is convergent.


Show that, for this set of values, the sum of the series is $(1+x)−1$.[4]





By differentiating the series $S$, show that
$(1+x)−2=1−2x+3x2−4x3+5x4−⋯$ [2]



By differentiating the equation obtained in part (c), show that
$(1+x)−3=1−3x+6x2−10x3+⋯$ [2]



Hence by recognising the pattern, deduce that for $n∈Z+$,
$(1+x)−n=1−nx+2!n(n+1)​x2−3!n(n+1)(n+2)​x3+⋯$ [4]



Now, we will determine how to generalize the expansion of $(1+x)q$ for
$q∈Q$.
Suppose $(1+x)q$ with $q∈Q$ can be written as the power
series
$$$a0​+a1​x+a2​x2+a3​x3+a4​x4+⋯$$$


By substituting $x=0$, find the value of $a0​$.[1]



By differentiating the series of $(1+x)q$ and evaluating
at $x=0$ find the value of $a1​$.[2]



By repeating the procedure of part (g) find the value
of $a2​$ and $a3​$.[4]



Hence, write down the first four terms of the series
expansion for $(1+x)q$ called the Extended Binomial
Theorem.[1]



Write down the power series for $1−x2​1​$,
including the first four terms.[3]



Hence, integrating the series found in part (j), find
the power series for $arcsinx$, including the first four
terms.[4]
list.markScheme:
Using the binomial theorem, we have
$$$(1−x)5​=k=0∑5​(k5​)(15−k)[(−x)k]=k=0∑5​(k5​)(−x)k=1−5x+10x2−10x3+5x4−x5​​$$$




The common ratio of the geometric series is
$$$r​=1−x​=−x​$$$
Hence, the geometric series is
convergent if
$$$−1​<−x<1​$$$
or equivalently
$$$​−1<x<1​​$$$


Using the formula for the sum of a geometric series, we get
$$$S​=1−(−x)1​=(1+x)−1​​$$$




Taking the derivative of the geometric series $S$ from part (b), we
get
$$$dxd​(1+x)−1−(1+x)−2​=dxd​[1−x+x2−x3+x4−x5+⋯]=−1+2x−3x2+4x3−5x4+⋯(1+x)−2=1−2x+3x2−4x3+5x4+⋯​​$$$


Taking the derivative of the expression found in part (c), we get
$$$dxd​(1+x)−2−2(1+x)−3​=dxd​[1−2x+3x2−4x3+5x4+⋯]=−2+6x−12x2+20x3+⋯(1+x)−3=1−3x+6x2−10x3+⋯​​$$$


We are looking for the first four coefficients of $x$ in the expansion of $(1+x)−n$. The following table shows these coefficients in the case where $n=1,2,3$ as obtained in parts (b), (c) and (d).


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1f1430da-ae17-409e-be49-96b5eacb028d/images/241707d9-81ea-4bf6-82b4-fac0dd2a51eb/aa907a.PNG)


Using Pascal's triangle,


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1f1430da-ae17-409e-be49-96b5eacb028d/images/43cfcef6-b7c8-4049-8890-b8c7cf0c63f3/aa907b.PNG)


Note that the coefficients of $x$ in our expansion follow a pattern of binomial coefficients and therefore we can write in our table:


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1f1430da-ae17-409e-be49-96b5eacb028d/images/d4c8fae9-f31c-47eb-b4e9-65e3828ca99a/aa907c.PNG)


Given that $nCr​=r!(n−r)!n!​$,
$$$​(1+x)−n=1−nx+2!n(n+1)​x2−3!n(n+1)(n+2)​x3+⋯​​$$$


Substituting $x=0$ into the equation, we get
$$$(1+0)q​=a0​+a1​(0)+a2​(0)2+a3​(0)3+⋯1=a0​​​$$$


Taking the derivative of the proposed series, we get
$$$dxd​(1+x)qq(1+x)q−1q(1+0)q−1​=dxd​[a0​+a1​x+a2​x2+a3​x3+a4​x4+⋯]=a1​+2a2​x+3a3​x2+4a4​x3+⋯=a1​+2a2​(0)+3a3​(0)2+4a4​(0)3+⋯a1​=q​​$$$


Taking the second and third derivatives of the proposed series, we
get
$$$dxd​q(1+x)q−1(q−1)q(1+x)q−2(q−1)q(1+0)q−2dxd​(q−1)q(1+x)q−2(q−2)(q−1)q(1+x)q−3(q−2)(q−1)q(1+0)q−3​=dxd​[a1​+2a2​x+3a3​x2+4a4​x3+⋯]=2a2​+6a3​x+12a4​x2+⋯=2a2​+6a3​(0)+12a4​(0)2+⋯a2​=2(q−1)q​​=dxd​[2a2​+6a3​x+12a4​x2+⋯]=6a3​+24a4​x+⋯=6a3​+24a4​(0)+⋯a3​=6(q−2)(q−1)q​​​$$$


According to the pattern found in parts (g) and (h), we obtain
$$$(1+x)q​=1+qx+2!(q−1)q​x2+3!(q−2)(q−1)q​x3+⋯​​$$$


Using the Extended Binomial Theorem, we get
$$$1−x2​1​​=(1+(−x2))−1/2=1+(−21​)(−x2)+2!(−21​−1)(−21​)​(−x2)2+3!(−21​−2)(−21​−1)(−21​)​(−x2)3+⋯=1+2x2​+83​(−x2)2+16−5​(−x2)3+⋯=1+2x2​+83​x4+165​x6+⋯​​$$$


Integrating the series found in part (j), we get
$$$∫1−x2​1​dx​=∫[1+2x2​+83​x4+165​x6+⋯]dxarcsinx=x+6x3​+403​x5+1125​x7+⋯​​$$$

list.title: Question 27
list.content:
Jack and John have decided to play a game. They will be rolling a die
seven times. One roll of a die is considered as one round of the game.
On each round, John agrees to pay Jack $4 if $1$ or $2$ is rolled, Jack
agrees to pay John $2 if $3,4,5$ or $6$ is rolled, and who is paid wins
the round. In the end, who earns money wins the game.


Show that the probability that Jack wins exactly two rounds is
$729224​$.  [3]





Explain why the total number of outcomes for the results of the
seven rounds is $128$.


Expand $(1+y)7$ and choose a suitable value of $y$ to prove
that
$$$128=(07​)+(17​)+(27​)+(37​)+(47​)+(57​)+(67​)+(77​).$$$


Give a meaning of the equality above in the context of the
seven
rounds.[4]







Find the expected amount of money earned by each player in the
game.


Who is expected to win the game?


Is this game fair? Justify your answer. [3]





Jack and John have decided to play the game again.


Find an expression for the probability that John wins five
rounds on the first game and two rounds on the second game. Give
your answer in the form
$$$(r7​)2[31​]s[32​]t$$$
where the values of $r,s$ and $t$ are to be found.


Use your answer to (d) (i) and seven similar expressions to
write down the probability that John wins a total of seven
rounds over two games as the sum of eight probabilities.


Hence prove that
$$$(714​)=k=0∑7​(k7​)2.$$$
[9]





Now Jack and John roll a die $12$ times. Let $A$ denote the number
of rounds Jack wins. The expected value of $A$ can be written as
$$$E[A]=r=0∑12​r(r12​)[b12a12−r​]$$$


Find the value of $a$ and $b$.


Differentiate the expansion of $(1+y)12$ to prove that the
expected
number of rolls Jack wins is $4$. [6]
list.markScheme:
The probability that Jack wins a round is $31​$.
Hence the probability that Jack wins exactly two rounds is
$$$(27​)[31​]2[32​]5​=[27⋅6​][321​][3525​]=367⋅25​=729224​​​$$$




On each round, either Jack wins or John wins. Hence in seven rounds, there are $27=128$ possible outcomes.


Using the binomial theorem, we have
$$$(1+y)7=k=0∑7​(k7​)yk(1)$$$
Hence, if we substitute $y=1$ in the equation $(1)$, we get
$$$128=∑k=07​(k7​)​$$$


The total number of outcomes equals to the sum of the number of ways Jack can win $k$ rounds over $k=0,1,2,…,7$.






The expected amount of money earned by Jack in the game is
$$$E[$ earned by Jack]​=7[($4)⋅31​+(−$2)⋅32​]=$0.00​​$$$
The expected amount of money earned by John in the game is
$$$E[$ earned by John]​=7[(−$4)⋅31​+($2)⋅32​]=$0.00​​$$$


Since no one is expected to earn money in the game, no one is expected to win the game.


Yes, this game is fair because no one is expected to win or lose the~game.






The probability that John wins a round is $32​$.
Hence the probability that John wins five rounds on the first
game and two rounds on the second game is
$$$[(57​)[32​]5[31​]2][(27​)[32​]2[31​]5]=(57​)2[32​]7[31​]7​$$$


Similarly as in (d) (i), the probability that John wins a total
of seven rounds over two games is
$$$k=0∑7​(k7​)2[32​]7[31​]7=[31427​]∑k=07​(k7​)2​$$$


Equivalently, the probability that John wins $7$ rounds out of
$14$ is
$$$(714​)[32​]7[31​]7=(714​)[31427​]$$$
Hence we obtain
$$$(714​)[31427​]​​=[31427​]​k=0∑7​(k7​)2​$$$
$$$(714​)=∑k=07​(k7​)2​$$$






The expected value of $A$ is
$$$E[A]​=r=0∑12​r(r12​)[31​]r[32​]12−r=r=0∑12​r(r12​)[312212−r​]​$$$
Hence
$a=2​$
and  $b=3​$


Using the binomial theorem, we have
$$$(1+y)12=k=0∑12​(k12​)yk(2)$$$
Hence, if we differentiate both sides of the equation $(2)$, we
get
$$$dyd​[(1+y)12]12(1+y)11​=dyd​[r=0∑12​(r12​)yr]=r=0∑12​r(r12​)yr−1(3)​$$$
To obtain $211312​$ on the left hand side and
$21−r$ on the right hand side of
the equation $(3)$, we need to substitute $y=21​$ in
this equation.
$$$12(1+21​)114⋅211312​​=r=0∑12​r(r12​)[21​]r−1=r=0∑12​r(r12​)[21−r](4)​$$$
Hence, if we rewrite the equation $(4)$, we obtain
$$$4​=r=0∑12​r(r12​)[312212−r​]​$$$
$$$4=E[A]​$$$
